results.title: Legacy : a promise for the future : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Six members of Melbourne Legacy give their individual stories of how they got into contact with Legacy. Whether they are survivors of war, employees of Legacy or the children of soldiers, Legacy manages make a significant impression on the lives of its members and provides inspiration for future generations.

results.title: Left out
results.creator_credit: Jim Purdy, John Kramer, John Spotton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film on unemployment and how it affects a family, as seen primarily through the eyes of a twelve-year-old. When Amy learns that she cannot go on a school field trip to Quebec City, she is devastated. Eventually, however, Amy grows to realize that a lack of money does not mean a lack of love, and that her parents try to compensate in other ways. Other elements in the film include the strain a man’s unemployment can place on husband and wife, and the tension it can create between parents and children. Part of a series of short dramatic films for children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Purdy, John Kramer, John Spotton and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Left-handed children: a guide for teachers and parents
results.brief_description: An instructional documentary for parents and teachers dealing with left-handed children. In addition to revealing interesting facts about the number of left-handed people in the community, “Left-handed children” provides vital tips for a range of activities as diverse as hand writing, using scissors, using a ruler, pencil-sharpening, calligraphy, using a computer keyboard and mouse, tying shoe-laces, craft-work, using kitchen utensils and playing sport. As left-handed children may be more vulnerable to feelings of self-doubt because of their difficulty in adopting ‘right-handed’ tools and approaches, this documentary is an essential and invaluable guide.

results.title: Lee Marvin: a personal portrait by John Boorman
results.creator_credit: John Boorman, Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.), BBC, American Movie Classics and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: The collaboration that took place between John Boorman and Lee Marvin on two films- ‘Point Blank’ (1967) and ‘Hell in the Pacific’ (1968) led to a mutual admiration and close friendship between the two men that lasted for nearly 20 years until Marvin’s death in 1987. This documentary records Boorman’s personal quest to understand the man who had such a profound effect on his own life and work. It includes interviews with William Hurt, Jim Jarmusch and Marvin’s widow, Pamela.

results.title: Lectures are a drag
results.brief_description: An “average” class of high school students is observed during a spirited discussion on the Bill of Rights. Techniques used by the teachers in directing the discussion are pointed out. At the end the students make statements on their feeling of involvement in the enquiry and discussion.

results.title: Leaving Las Vegas (D)
results.creator_credit: Mike Figgis, Anne Stewart, Lila Cazès and Initial Productions (US)
results.brief_description: This unlikely love story between a prostitute and an alcoholic won Nicholas Cage an Oscar for Best Actor as well as accolades from various other film festivals. Alcoholic screenwriter Ben, (Nicholas Cage) having lost his wife, child and now his job heads to Las Vegas on a mission to drink himself to death. He picks up prostitute Sera (Elizabeth Shue), they share a night together, numerous drinks and form a semblance of a relationship. She is aware of his mission, his lack of commitment and his love for alcohol which may surpass that of his feelings for her, but desperately clings to him for companionship. They form a relationship on the agreement that she will not ask him to stop drinking. The film is clouded by the halo of Ben’s alcoholism and Sera’s unhappy situation, but is lifted by the strange tenderness they share. Also starring Julian Sands and Richard Lewis.

results.title: Leaving it to the experts
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In order to be an effective member of a community is it an individual’s responsibility to keep informed? Two farmers argue the point when one of them is invited to join a group studying international affairs. He says a farmer has enough to do with his own problems, and the world’s affairs can be best left to the experts. The audience is invited to carry the discussion further.

results.title: Leaves
results.brief_description: A study of the various types of leaves and their structure and function; the parts of a leaf are studied in detail, and a cross-section shows the arrangement of the cells and veins and the actual process of transforming water and minerals and gases into food for the plant.

results.title: Leave no man behind
results.creator_credit: Les Maher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Even though Les Maher believed you should never leave a man behind, there was a time in Vietnam that he had to make the decision to do so. Decades later, Maher has never forgotten and endeavoured to fulfil his promise.
